articles.headline: Free Power From Freeways? China Is Testing Roads Paved With Solar Panels
articles.snippet: Western countries have been looking into putting solar panels on roads for years. The Chinese have done it, installing panels on a downhill section of a mountain road.
articles.abstract: Western countries have been looking into putting solar panels on roads for years. The Chinese have done it, installing panels on a downhill section of a mountain road.
articles.lead_paragraph: JINAN, China — On a smoggy afternoon, huge log carriers and oil tankers thundered down a highway and hurtled around a curve at the bottom of a hill. Only a single, unreinforced guardrail stood between the traffic and a ravine.

articles.headline: Sessions Says Domestic and Gang Violence Are Not Grounds for Asylum
articles.snippet: The attorney general reversed an immigration appeals court decision granting asylum to a Salvadoran woman whose husband had sexually and physically abused her.
articles.abstract: The attorney general reversed an immigration appeals court decision granting asylum to a Salvadoran woman whose husband had sexually and physically abused her.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Jeff Sessions on Monday made it all but impossible for asylum seekers to gain entry into the United States by citing fears of domestic abuse or gang violence, in a ruling that could have a broad effect on the flow of migrants from Central America.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Caitlin Dickerson

articles.headline: How Net Neutrality Actually Ended Long Before This Week
articles.snippet: The internet was supposed to operate outside communications monopolies. Now it is run by giants — and net neutrality didn’t stand a chance, our tech columnist says.
articles.abstract: The internet was supposed to operate outside communications monopolies. Now it is run by giants — and net neutrality didn’t stand a chance, our tech columnist says.
articles.lead_paragraph: I remember the first time I ever heard about net neutrality. It was around 2004 or 2005, and when the full idea was explained to me — hey, let’s prevent phone and cable companies from influencing the content we see online — I was surprised there was even a fight about the idea.

articles.headline: E-Commerce Might Help Solve the Mystery of Low Inflation
articles.snippet: When it’s easier to comparison shop online, businesses are less likely to raise prices — but you wouldn’t know that by looking at official inflation data.
articles.abstract: When it’s easier to comparison shop online, businesses are less likely to raise prices — but you wouldn’t know that by looking at official inflation data.
articles.lead_paragraph: Unemployment is sinking and businesses are churning out more goods and services. Yet even with the economy standing on tippy toes, prices and wages are climbing a lot more slowly than anyone has expected.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Trump and Kim See New Chapter for Nations After Summit
articles.snippet: The president and the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, signed a document that Mr. Trump called “comprehensive,” though it was short on details.
articles.abstract: The president and the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, signed a document that Mr. Trump called “comprehensive,” though it was short on details.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — President Trump shook hands with Kim Jong-un of North Korea on Tuesday and offered a major concession during the first summit meeting between their nations, a momentous step in an improbable courtship between the world’s largest nuclear power and the most reclusive one.

articles.headline: Unscripted Moments Steal the Show at Trump-Kim Singapore Summit
articles.snippet: A peek inside the presidential limo, a joke about looking thin, a splashy video showing the benefits of peace. The political theatrics were riveting.
articles.abstract: A peek inside the presidential limo, a joke about looking thin, a splashy video showing the benefits of peace. The political theatrics were riveting.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — The president of the United States pulled out an iPad and showed the leader of North Korea a slick, Hollywood-style trailer presenting the North’s possible future.

articles.headline: Can’t Sleep? Let Bob Ross Help You Find Some Happy Little Zzzs
articles.snippet: For years, insomniacs watched “The Joy of Painting” to doze off. Now, the maker of a meditation app wants everyone else to fall asleep, too.
articles.abstract: For years, insomniacs watched “The Joy of Painting” to doze off. Now, the maker of a meditation app wants everyone else to fall asleep, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, insomniacs have been lulled to sleep by the dulcet voice of Bob Ross, the bushy-haired painter whose PBS show, “The Joy of Painting,” rose to popularity in the 1990s and has lately enjoyed a second life on YouTube. Now, the maker of a popular meditation app hopes Mr. Ross will put everyone else to sleep, too.
